articles.headline: Trump Signs Budget Deal to Raise Spending and Reopen Government
articles.snippet: Government funding expired at midnight after Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky held up the Senate’s vote on a budget deal, but both chambers eventually gave their approval.
articles.abstract: Government funding expired at midnight after Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky held up the Senate’s vote on a budget deal, but both chambers eventually gave their approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday morning signed into law a far-reaching budget deal that will boost spending by hundreds of billions of dollars and allow the federal government to reopen after a brief shutdown.

articles.headline: Drug Industry Wages Opioid Fight Using an Anti-Addiction Ally
articles.snippet: Pharmaceutical companies have enlisted the support of a prominent anti-addiction advocate as they battle the perception that they created an epidemic.
articles.abstract: Pharmaceutical companies have enlisted the support of a prominent anti-addiction advocate as they battle the perception that they created an epidemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Minnesota lawmakers prepared to push a proposed tax on opioid sales in November, the pharmaceutical industry lobbyists who opposed the bill set up a meeting with its sponsors, and they brought an unusual guest: Jessica Hulsey Nickel, a prominent anti-addiction advocate in Washington.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: It’s Hard to Believe, but Syria’s War Is Getting Even Worse
articles.snippet: The conflict has broken into several small wars, and the carnage is reaching a new peak, upending any assumptions it might be nearing an end.
articles.abstract: The conflict has broken into several small wars, and the carnage is reaching a new peak, upending any assumptions it might be nearing an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Half a dozen newborns, blinking and arching their backs, were carried from a burning hospital hit by airstrikes. A bombed apartment house collapsed, burying families. Medics doused patients with water after a suspected chlorine attack, one of five in Syria since the start of the year.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: Stocks Plunge as Market Enters ‘Correction’ Territory
articles.snippet: Wall Street, roiled this week by the most turbulence in years, broke from a brief respite on Thursday, entering a market correction.
articles.abstract: Wall Street, roiled this week by the most turbulence in years, broke from a brief respite on Thursday, entering a market correction.
articles.lead_paragraph: After watching stocks march higher for nearly nine years, investors are suddenly confronting a new reality: The long, smooth ride is over. And it doesn’t feel good.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Cryptocurrencies Come to Campus
articles.snippet: From New York University to Berkeley, Bitcoin has set off a dash to understand the technology and economic risks of virtual currency.
articles.abstract: From New York University to Berkeley, Bitcoin has set off a dash to understand the technology and economic risks of virtual currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — While the price of Bitcoin has dropped since Christmas, the virtual currency boom has shown no signs of cooling off in the more august precincts of America’s elite universities.

articles.headline: From (Crumbling) Airport to (Broken) Escalators: An Infrastructure Odyssey
articles.snippet: President Trump has talked about a huge infrastructure investment, but can we even make the trains run on time? Our beleaguered columnist is skeptical.
articles.abstract: President Trump has talked about a huge infrastructure investment, but can we even make the trains run on time? Our beleaguered columnist is skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Sunday before last, as I emerged tired and dispirited from Penn Station after a two-plus hour trip from the Newark airport, I found myself pondering President Trump’s campaign pledge “to spur $1 trillion in infrastructure investment,” a theme he raised  in this year’s State of the Union address and is expected to address again next week.

articles.headline: The Quiet Diplomacy to Save the Olympics in a Nuclear Standoff
articles.snippet: Organizers worried that the North would spoil the Winter Games in Pyeongchang. But after months of anxiety and failed diplomacy, there was a deal.
articles.abstract: Organizers worried that the North would spoil the Winter Games in Pyeongchang. But after months of anxiety and failed diplomacy, there was a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In late December, a group of teenagers from North Korea traveled to the Chinese city of Kunming to play in an obscure under-15 soccer tournament. On the field, under a wintry sun, they faced teams from China and South Korea. Off the field, there was an unusual spectator: Choi Moon-soon, the governor of the province in South Korea hosting the Winter Olympics.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez, Choe Sang-Hun and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: We All Have a Stake in the Stock Market, Right? Guess Again
articles.snippet: Wall Street’s up and downs have little impact on the income or wealth of most Americans, despite the bromides of politicians on both sides of the aisle.
articles.abstract: Wall Street’s up and downs have little impact on the income or wealth of most Americans, despite the bromides of politicians on both sides of the aisle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Take a deep breath and relax.

articles.headline: Top Trump Aides Are Said to Have Long Known About Abuse Accusations
articles.snippet: White House officials conceded they “could have done better” in the way they handled accusations against the staff secretary who resigned Wednesday after two ex-wives publicly accused him of abusing them.
articles.abstract: White House officials conceded they “could have done better” in the way they handled accusations against the staff secretary who resigned Wednesday after two ex-wives publicly accused him of abusing them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials conceded Thursday that they regretted the way they handled accusations against Rob Porter, the staff secretary who resigned Wednesday after two former wives publicly accused him of abusing them. But they refused to provide any information about when President Trump’s most senior advisers first learned about the episodes.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis, Katie Rogers and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Republicans Learn to Love Deficit Spending They Once Loathed
articles.snippet: After years of professing fiscal discipline, Republicans are embracing budget deficits as the nation’s debt swells.
articles.abstract: After years of professing fiscal discipline, Republicans are embracing budget deficits as the nation’s debt swells.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Big government is officially back in style.

articles.headline: Insurance 101: Butler Undergrads Write Coverage for Dogs and Pianos
articles.snippet: Most undergraduates never discover that insurance is interesting. Butler University is trying to change that through a student-run insurance company.
articles.abstract: Most undergraduates never discover that insurance is interesting. Butler University is trying to change that through a student-run insurance company.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Can you trust college students with pepper spray? If they sell blankets to other students to make money, might they be contributing to a bedbug infestation in the dorms? And how many drunken teenagers are dancing on the campus pianos instead of playing Shostakovich?

articles.headline: Developers Seek $6 Million Tax Break for Trump-Managed Hotel
articles.snippet: The president’s family business has teamed up with local developers on a Mississippi Delta hotel. The developers want financial relief from the state.
articles.abstract: The president’s family business has teamed up with local developers on a Mississippi Delta hotel. The developers want financial relief from the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Trump’s family business prepares to open a hotel in the Mississippi Delta this fall, its local development partners have asked the State of Mississippi to subsidize the project with up to $6 million in tax breaks, according to documents obtained through an open records request.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Ben Protess
